I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I  submit for  your  approval  the  report  and recommendation  on  a proposed  policy-based 

 
1. 
grant to Solomon Islands for the Improved Fiscal Sustainability Reform Program.1 
 
2. 
The program is part of long-standing and coordinated assistance provided by the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  support  the  efforts  of  the  Government  of  Solomon  Islands  to 
implement  policy  and  institutional  reforms  that  have  helped  to  progressively  improve 
macroeconomic  management,  fiscal  sustainability,  the  business  climate,  public  financial 
management (PFM), and service delivery.2 The program builds on these previous policy-based 
programs  and  technical  assistance  (TA)  to  further  improve  PFM,  fiscal  sustainability,  and  the 
private sector investment climate.3 
 

II. 

PROGRAM AND RATIONALE 

Background and Development Constraints 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Development  context.  Solomon  Islands  is  largely  rural  with  85%  of  its  population  of 
652,000  living  in  villages  in  nine  provinces  spread  across  20  islands.  Income-generating 
opportunities are scarce and predominantly based on natural resources—fisheries, forestry, and 
mining.  Providing  infrastructure  and  services  to  this  dispersed  population  is  difficult  and  costly 
and  helps  constrain business  and investment growth.  Although  poverty  has  declined in recent 
years, Solomon Islands has the lowest gross national income per  capita among ADB’s Pacific 
developing member countries.4 
 
4. 
Successive reformist governments since 2006 have improved PFM practices, made fiscal 
policy  sustainable,  and  increased  investment  levels.  This  along  with  robust  economic  growth, 
including an average of 3.0% per annum during 2015–2017, resulted in per capita incomes almost 
doubling since the global financial crisis.5 However, economic problems remain. First, the country 
continues  to  exhibit  characteristics  of  a  fragile  state.  The  government  has  limited  reach  and 
effectiveness, its economic policy needs to be actively managed, and the country is vulnerable to 
shocks  such  as  civil  unrest  and  natural  disasters. 6  Second,  unsustainable  logging,  which 
accounted for about 17% of domestic revenue and two-thirds of exports in 2017, has been the 
biggest driver of growth, and it is expected to decline over the medium term (footnote 4). Third, 
annual population growth of about 2.3% means high levels of economic growth are required to 
continue per capita income growth. According to the International Monetary Fund (IMF), the main 
macroeconomic  challenges  facing  policy  makers  in  Solomon  Islands  are  the  need  to  improve 
access to basic services, strengthen resilience, and generate new sources of economic growth.7 
These economic challenges coupled with significant government capacity constraints to develop 
and implement policy effectively, make reform challenging and requiring significant development 
partner support.

 In  the  wake  of  the  global  financial  crisis  in  2009,  the  government  and  development 
5. 
partners established the Core Economic Working Group (CEWG) to develop a joint framework 
for mitigating the impacts of the crisis and building resilience to future shocks.8 The CEWG now 
coordinates the government and development partners on policy reform priorities associated with 
budget  support.  The  framework,  called  the  policy  reform  matrix,  includes  a  list  of  high-priority 
reform actions from the National Development Strategy (NDS) that will help achieve the country’s 
vision of improving the social and economic livelihoods of all Solomon Islanders.9 ADB helped the 
government  achieve  the  following  reforms  between  2010  and  2015:  (i)  the  establishment  of  a 
Budget Strategy Committee to  improve interagency coordination; (ii) regular consultations with 
civil  society  organizations,  including  women’s  groups,  on  the  national  budget  to  improve 
community awareness and strengthen budget accountability and transparency; (iii) the adoption 
of a new debt management strategy to improve overall fiscal discipline; and (iv) the amendment 
of the Registration of Business Names Act to facilitate improved processes for registering formal 
businesses.10 
 
6. 
Following the November 2014 general election, the country’s fiscal position deteriorated 
because of changes in government priorities, a waning commitment to the CEWG process, and 
reform  slippage.  After  several  years  of  surpluses,  fiscal  deficits  emerged  during  2015–2017 
(Table 1). The buildup of cash reserves were drawn down to finance the fiscal expansion.11 The 
low cash balance fell from 3.6 months of recurrent spending at  the end of 2015 to 0.7 months 
at  the  end  of  2017.  This  was  below  the  2-month  target  of  total  recurrent  expenditure 
recommended by the IMF, and reduces the government’s fiscal buffers against shocks. Public 
debt also increased to finance infrastructure investments although the 2017 IMF–World Bank 
Debt  Sustainability  Analysis  concluded  that  the  risk  of  debt  distress  remained  moderate 
(footnote 7). 
 
7. 
Since the leadership changed in November 2017, policy dialogue has resumed through 
the CEWG and reform momentum has increased.12 The government has made a concerted effort 
to reestablish macroeconomic and fiscal stability by targeting lower budget deficits in 2018 and 
2019. 13 Its  fiscal  consolidation  program  is  a  positive  step.  Although  the  capital  development 
budget  almost  halved from  11.8% to 6.5%  of gross domestic  product  in  the  2018  budget,  it  is 
unlikely to have substantial adverse economic growth impacts because the development budget 
is perennially under spent.14 Delays in government payments have also had flow-on effects to the 
private sector, particularly businesses with government supply contracts.  
 
8. 
Therefore,  the  government  is  keen  to  prioritize  reforms  that  strengthen  public  sector 
management and service delivery. These objectives are consistent with the (i) first objective of 
the NDS (sustained and inclusive economic growth); (ii) ADB’s Pacific Approach, 2016–2020 and

9. 
Public  financial  management  needs  strengthening.  The  deterioration  of  the  fiscal 
position  between  2015  and  2017,  accompanied  by  a  rise  in  expenditure  arrears,  reflects 
challenges  in  PFM.  In  June  2018,  an  IMF  review  of  the  PFM  Reform  Roadmap,  2014–2017 
recommended actions to strengthen overall PFM integrity. The Ministry of Finance and Treasury 
(MOFT) has good policies and processes to implement the PFM Act (2013) as envisaged, but the 
focus  is  to  institutionalize  these  existing  good  practices  by  enacting  regulations  under  this  act 
(e.g.,  ensuring  all  projects  that  require  debt  financing  include  an  economic  analysis  so  that 
macroeconomic and debt level implications can be assessed). 
 
10. 
Eradicating  corruption  is  also  a  critical  element  of  the  government’s  PFM  agenda. 
However,  key  mechanisms  to  perform  checks  and  balances  on  executive  powers  are  lacking, 
especially  in  relation  to  accountability  measures  for  public  office  holders  and  civil  servants. 
Combating  corruption  is  spread  across  various  institutions,  and  this  diffused  approach  has 
weakened anticorruption efforts and contributed to persistent corruption. The Leadership Code 
Commission within the Office of the Prime Minister has a legislative mandate to inquire into the 
conduct of public servants and officers of public agencies, but it has been ineffective. Meanwhile, 
the ombudsperson, established to deal with maladministration, commenced its operations in 2018. 
The government recognizes that measures  to improve transparency,  strengthen anticorruption 
practices, and protect persons who report instances of corruption in good faith and on reasonable

 grounds must be promoted in accordance with Article 33 of the United Nations Convention against 
Corruption, which Solomon Islands has ratified. 
 
11. 
Fiscal management needs to be sustainable. Widening fiscal deficits and the reduced 
2018 development budget in the context of projected declining logging revenues underscore the 
need to prioritize better expenditure and make careful fiscal adjustments in 2018 and 2019. Fiscal 
buffers are low, with the cash balance below IMF’s target (footnote 7). Regarding expenditure, 
payment  arrears  have  reemerged.  Greater  restraint  is  also  needed  for  discretionary  recurrent 
expenditures on Parliamentarian tertiary scholarships and shipping grants, which are all disbursed 
through Members of Parliament. Although these programs aim to provide public services unmet 
by  the  government  to  the  rural  population,  there  needs  to  be  greater  accountability  and 
transparency  in  their  use,  particularly  in  assessing  their  development  impact.  Tertiary 
scholarships and shipping grants, for example, increased as a share of the development budget 
from 1.7% to 5.1% between 2014 and 2017. Government debt levels are sustainable and debt 
servicing levels are affordable, but the downside risks are high (footnote 7). 
  
In July 2018, a $28.9 million supplementary budget was approved by Parliament to finance 
12. 
additional expenditure on items identified as being omitted from the 2018 budget. In line with the 
government’s  fiscal  consolidation  efforts,  line  ministries  were  advised  that  new  or  additional 
expenditures would be accommodated only if there was a commensurate increase in revenues. 
In  addition,  expenditure  arrears  and  all  legitimate  contractual  commitments  and  ongoing  fixed 
costs would be prioritized. In this context, the IMF recommended that the government focus on 
measures to rebuild the cash balance, strengthen tax compliance, streamline exemptions, and 
clear expenditure arrears (footnote 15). 
 
13. 
Increased  private  sector  investment.  The  country  needs  increased  private  sector 
investment,  particularly  investment  that  will  diversify  the  economy,  to  grow  the  formal  private 
sector to address employment and income challenges.16 The government plays an important role 
in establishing an investment climate where private businesses can thrive. The NDS includes the 
following  reform  priorities:  (i)  encourage  greater  private  sector  involvement  in  delivering 
infrastructure services; (ii) undertake a comprehensive review of the tax system that encourages 
domestic  and  foreign  investment;  and  (iii)  encourage  efforts  that  facilitate  business  access  to 
finance,  in  particular,  by  developing  new  products  to  enable  greater  moveable  asset-based 
lending using the secured transaction registry. ADB-supported reforms between 2010 and 2017 
to  enhance  the  business  environment  and  improve  private  sector  investment  included 
streamlining  foreign  investment  processes,  reforming  business  laws,  and  improving  the 
governance and commercial performance of state-owned enterprises.17 
 
14. 
Despite positive growth forecasts (Table 1), there are still many challenges to encouraging 
the private sector to grow. Policy development processes to achieve effective investment climate 
reforms are fragmented; infrastructure projects need rigorous economic analysis to ensure scarce 
public  funds  achieve  the  greatest  returns;  investments  in  education,  particularly  vocational 
education and skills training, need increasing; and the financial sector needs to facilitate greater 
access  to  finance.  Specifically,  an  impediment  is  that  the  tax  structure  is  outdated,  inefficient, 
complex, expensive to administer, and anticompetitive. The tax system imposes high compliance 
costs  on  taxpayers;  discourages  people  from  becoming  taxpayers,  particularly  women;  and 
encourages tax  avoidance  and  evasion.  Importantly,  the  tax  system  does  not  actively  support

 Policy Reform and ADB’s Value Addition 

growth;  for  example,  it  does  not  systematically  support  exports  and  instead  relies  upon 
distortionary exemptions for exporting industries. The IMF has stated that the government’s focus 
on tax reform will help to significantly improve the investment climate by making the tax system 
more efficient, fair, and equitable (footnote 15). More generally, the economy is uncompetitive, 
and policy and regulatory settings do not encourage competition, the protection of consumers, or 
the economic empowerment of women. Finally, Solomon Islands has a narrow economic base 
with an overdependence on unsustainable logging. The economic base needs to be broadened 
to  reduce  reliance  on  the  forestry  sector  and  to  make  the  economy  more  resilient  to  external 
shocks. The government believes that the minerals sector has the greatest potential to manage 
the transition away from unsustainable logging. However, several challenges, such as the lack of 
transparency in issuing mining licenses, disclosing revenues, and applying fiscal incentives, need 
to be effectively addressed. 
 
B. 
 
15. 
The first ADB mission to start policy dialogue for this program took place in September 
2017.  However,  the  resumption  of  the  CEWG  in  January  2018  increased  momentum.  The 
government  and  development  partners  agreed on  three  strategic  themes  (strengthening  PFM, 
improving fiscal management  and sustainability,  and  enabling  drivers  of economic growth and 
promoting investment) that would provide the basis for reform priorities to be supported by policy-
based operations.18 These are all areas of long-standing ADB policy engagement (footnote 2). 
The  program  has  completed  the  implementation  of  eight  reforms  critical  to  addressing  the 
development challenges. 
 
Reform area 1: Public financial management. A policy priority of MOFT is to improve 
16. 
budget  outcomes  and  increase transparency  by  strengthening  PFM.  Coupled  with  institutional 
reforms  to fight  corruption  and  protect  whistleblowers,  this  will  help  protect  the  integrity  of  the 
national budget and work towards transforming policy priorities into improved service delivery.  
 
17.  MOFT completed the review of the PFM Reform Roadmap, 2014–2017 in August 2018, 
and the Minister of Finance and Treasury endorsed the PFM Action Plan, 2019–2020 based on 
the outcomes of the review. The action plan reflects the government’s most urgent priorities in 
line  with  IMF’s  recommendations  to  (i)  improve  budget  credibility,  (ii)  implement  commitment 
controls, (iii) institutionalize a comprehensive approach to cash management, (iv) clear all existing 
expenditure arrears while executing the 2018 budget, and (v) support greater accountability of 
discretionary  funds. 19  MOFT  has  also  developed  a  new  regulation  for  improving  debt 
management that came into force in September 2018. This regulation describes the process to 
raise new debt and will help ensure limited debt funding finances those projects with the greatest 
returns to the country. MOFT is working to further strengthen PFM processes by developing an 
additional  eight  regulations  under  the  PFM  Act  (2013)  to  provide  more  detailed  operational 
guidance  on  PFM  practices  such  as  the  budget  process,  management  of  public  funds,  and 
procurement.  
 
18. 
The government’s commitment to anticorruption is evidenced by the successful passing 
of legislation such as the Anti-Corruption Act (2018) and the Whistle-Blower Protection Act (2018). 
Among other things, these acts will establish the Anti-Corruption Independent Commission, which 
will  have  the  ability  to  investigate  and  prosecute  corruption,  build  capacity  for  corruption  risk 
assessments,  develop  a clear  code  of  conduct for  public  office  holders and civil  servants,  and 

                                                
18 Development Coordination (accessible from the list of the linked documents Appendix 2). 
19 IMF. 2018. Solomon Islands: Strengthening the Fundamentals of Public Finance Management. Washington, DC. 

5 

 

 promote  civil  society  participation  in  raising  awareness  and  reporting  corruption.  The  United 
Nations  Pacific  Regional  Anti-Corruption  Program  supported  the  government’s  efforts  to 
develop these bills and ensure they meet international obligations and are relevant to the 
local context.20 
 
19. 
Reform area 2: Fiscal sustainability. In line with IMF’s policy advice (footnote 7), MOFT 
is committed to strengthening the country’s resilience to shocks. This program enabled increases 
in revenues, reduced expenditure and started rebuilding fiscal buffers.  
 
20.  MOFT  certified  that  expenditure  arrears  totaling  $17.8  million  in  2017  have  been  paid. 
These arrears to private sector contractors were for public works. The nonpayment of invoices 
when  they  are  due  has  implications  for  firms  and  may  discourage  them  from  taking  future 
government  contracts.  However,  some  arrears  have  built  up  again  in  2018,  and  MOFT  has 
confirmed that all outstanding arrears will be paid by the end of 2018. MOFT has asked for TA to 
improve cash management to help prevent arrears in the future. 

 
Overall domestic revenue levels (excluding budget support) have increased by 4.8% on a 
21. 
year-on-year basis led by increased logging, improved compliance, and annual updates of excise 
taxes.  According  to  MOFT  modelling,  amendments  to  the  Goods  Tax  Act  and  reforms  to  the 
administration of withholding taxes will result in additional annual revenues of $5.1 million. The 
Goods Tax Act amendments will ensure that imported goods are taxed on the value of the goods 
through  a  prescribed  formula,  which  is  in  line  with  international  practice.  The  withholding  tax 
reforms  help  to  ensure  that  activities  that  fall  outside  the  pay-as-you-earn  system,  such  as 
professional  services,  are  captured  in  the  tax  net.  Similarly,  according  to  MOFT  modelling, 
increases  in  excise  taxes  collected  on  alcohol  and  tobacco  will  result  in  additional  annual 
revenues of $1.9 million. In the consultations conducted, the Solomon Islands Women in Business 
Association was included to understand the implications for women-owned businesses. 
 
Concerted action has reduced overall public expenditure from $516.8 million in 2017 to 
22. 
$507.1 million in 2018.21 Discretionary expenditure was reduced by 86% on new Parliamentarian 
tertiary scholarship awards and by 84% on shipping grants. The 2019 budget strategy goes further 
and proposes to remove both programs in line with the government’s fiscal consolidation efforts. 
These policies are in line with the IMF’s recommendations (para. 6). 

 
23. 
Reform area 3: Private sector investment climate. Solomon Islands needs increased 
private  sector  investment  that  will  diversify  the  economy  to  address  employment  and  income 
challenges. The program has enabled a tax review to start, new policies introduced to broaden 
the productive base, and a new policy to encourage greater competition in the economy. 
 
24.  MOFT has begun a comprehensive review of the tax system with a view to raising revenue 
in an economically efficient way without discouraging individuals and businesses from contributing 
to  the  national  economy  by  working,  earning  income,  saving,  and  investing.  The  Minister  of 
Finance and Treasury launched the review with discussion documents in November 2017, and 
these are available for review on  MOFT’s website.  The Cabinet also approved the time-bound 
work plan for review and consultations, which have commenced, including with women groups 
such as the Solomon Islands Women in Business Association. Consultations with women groups 
are important to understand the impact potential reforms will have on women, and adjustments 
can be made as necessary. MOFT is preparing early drafts of bills, and is targeting bills to be

 presented to the new government in 2019 for consideration, and then tabling in Parliament in the 
second half of 2019. 
 
25. 
Logging has been the primary source of government revenue and foreign exchange since 
the 1990s. However, regulation of the sector is weak and current logging volumes—estimated at 
2.7 million cubic meters in 2017—far exceed the sustainable threshold of 350,000 cubic meters. 
The sustainable forestry policy outlines how current regulations will be better enforced; targets a 
reduction  in  export  volumes;  encourages  sustainable  harvesting  and  forestry  rehabilitation, 
including the enforcement of environmental impact assessments; minimizes the misclassification 
of round logs exports; and promotes downstream processing. In addition, to minimize the impact 
of  the  transition  to  lowering  logging  exports,  the  government  has  adopted  a  National  Minerals 
Policy  that  positions  mining  as  a  new  driver  of  growth.  According  to  the  World  Bank,  mining 
appears to be the only sector with any prospect of filling the macroeconomic space occupied by 
logging.22 The policy helps achieve this by providing a more certain regulatory environment for 
mining and outlining activities to strengthen institutional capacity for Ministry of Mines staff. 
 
The Cabinet approved the competition and consumer policy in August 2018 that covers 
26. 
issues such as international best practice principles, government business activities, consumer 
protection,  competition  law,  institutional  arrangements,  and  international  trade.  The  main 
objective of the competition and consumer policy is to promote competition in Solomon Islands’ 
markets to support economic growth that is sustainable and inclusive. The next step is to examine 
legislation and regulations to see  what reforms are needed to support a competitive economy. 
ADB  will  support  this  work.  The  competition  and  consumer  policy  defines  inclusive  economic 
growth  as  economic  growth  that  reduces  poverty,  increases  employment  opportunities,  and 
ensures  that  policies  and  practices  facilitate  women’s  access  to  economic  resources  and 
opportunities. 
 
27. 
Post-program  partnership  framework.  The  policy  dialogue  process  made  clear  that, 
across  the  reform  areas,  several  follow-up  reform  steps  will  be  crucial  and  could  benefit  from 
further  ADB  and  development  partner  support.  The  government  and  ADB  agreed  on  a  post-
program partnership framework (PPPF) that would ensure that recently implemented reforms are 
imbedded, there is support for the next phase of associated and more substantive reforms, and 
ensure the program’s sustainability beyond 2018. A PPPF has been used successfully in other 
Pacific developing member countries to provide the basis for ongoing policy dialogue in years that 
ADB does not provide policy financing.23 The PPPF guides the government in sustaining efforts 
in  each  of  the  program  reform  areas,  and  MOFT  and  ADB  will  jointly  monitor  implementation. 
Details of the PPPF actions are presented in Appendix 4. 
 
28. 
ADB value addition. ADB’s experience and strong relationship with the government has 
played  an  important  role  in  identifying  and  implementing  critical  reforms.  To  aid  reform 
implementation  in  2018,  ADB  has  been  engaged  in  joint  analytical  work  and  policy  dialogue 
across all reform areas and has directly supported the preparation of the PFM Action Plan, 2018–
2019; the tax policy framework review; and the development of a competition policy. ADB will also 
continue  to  support  reform  momentum  including  entrenching  completed  reforms,  program 
sustainability, and implementation of the PPPF through new and ongoing TA (footnotes 10 and 
17)  in  close  collaboration  with  other  development  partners. 24 The  TA  support  will  also  help 
overcome the significant government capacity constraints which inhibits reform progress.

 Impacts of the Reform 

29. 
The  program  is  aligned  to  ADB’s  Strategy  2030,  particularly  the  operational  priorities 
related  to  strengthening  governance  and  institutional  capacity  and  accelerating  progress  in 
gender equality. The program also reflects Strategy 2030 approach to fragile and conflict-affected 
situations and small island developing states. Strategy 2030 requires ADB’s support in fragile and 
conflict-affected  situations  to  focus  on  institutional  development  and  governance  reforms. 
Similarly for small island developing states, Strategy 2030 emphasizes institutional strengthening 
to  support  countries’  efforts  to  manage  financial  and  economic  risk;  improve  the  business 
environment;  strengthen  the  quality  of  public  service  delivery,  and  promote  private  sector-led 
growth.  
 
30. 
Development partner coordination. The program is fully integrated with the CEWG. The 
program is aligned with the policy operations of the governments of Australia and New Zealand, 
the  European  Union,  and  the  World  Bank.  ADB  and  the  IMF  also  maintain  a  strong  working 
relationship in Solomon Islands. Based on this cooperation, ADB, the World Bank, and the IMF 
share a common view on the macroeconomic and structural reform priorities (footnote 15).25 
 
C. 
 
31. 
The  effect  of  the  reforms  that  the  program  has  helped  the  government  achieve  is 
strengthened public sector management and service delivery. Policy actions implemented under 
the first reform area will help improve the quality of budget systems and institutions. This supports 
the expectation that the program’s PFM reform actions will help the government maintain fiscal 
deficits below IMF’s recommended levels. Policy actions implemented under the second reform 
area provide the basis for improved budget execution, expenditure quality, and tax administration 
and compliance. In addition, new tax measures that were introduced have helped generate more 
revenue, which will rebuild cash reserves and provide fiscal space to respond to shocks. Policy 
actions implemented under the third reform area will support the shift to an economy that is broad-
based, competitive, and encourages the participation of women in the economy and a tax system 
that supports economic growth and is business friendly.26 
 
D. 
 
The  government  has  requested  a  grant  not  exceeding  $5.0  million  from  ADB’s  Special 
32. 
Funds resources (Asian Development Fund) to help finance the program. The World Bank, the 
governments of Australia and New Zealand, and the European Union will provide $16.4 million in 
cofinancing.27 The program will help the government meet its 2018 total financing requirements, 
which  are  estimated  at  $47.4  million  without  budget  support.  The  proposed  grant  size  was 
determined after considering the government’s commitment to stronger fiscal management, the 
country’s development financing needs, and the availability of financing from other development 
partners and sources. Without this program, parallel budget support programs from Australia and 
New Zealand would be unlikely, and the fiscal position would be significantly worse. 
 
33. 
Program  modality.  A  stand-alone,  policy-based  operation  is  proposed,  and  all  policy 
actions  have  been  completed.  A  policy-based  operation  is  appropriate  given  its  suitability  to 
improve  the  policy  and  institutional  environment  for  enhanced  efficiency  in  public  sector 
management,  its  use  of  resources,  and  the  government’s  commitment  to  policy  reform  as

Development Financing Needs and Budget Support 

8 

 

 evidenced by the revival of the CEWG. A stand-alone modality is considered appropriate based 
on a number of factors including (i) previous successful ADB operations in Solomon Islands using 
this modality; (ii) all CEWG development partners used this approach; (iii) the strong incentive 
structure for the new reformist government following a 2-year lapse of policy dialogue; (iv) with 
national elections scheduled for early 2019, this modality is appropriate given the potential for a 
change  in government;  and  (v)  leveraging  reform  when  the  political  environment  is  supportive 
recognizes  the  country’s  fragile  and  conflict-affected  status  and  the  need  to  build  resilience  to 
external  shocks.  The  potential  weakening  of  the  government  reform  commitment  in  2019  has 
been mitigated through a PPPF that contains long-standing reform priorities drawn from the NDS 
2016–2035, the demonstrated success of previous stand-alone programs that were negotiated 
with previous governments, and new TA to support implementation of the PPPF (footnotes 9 and 
24). The program is aligned with a government-led, multi-partner reform effort.  
 
E. 
 
34. 
The program period is from September 2017 to December 2018. Program funding will be 
provided as a single tranche grant of $5.0 million and will be withdrawn  when the government 
meets the conditions for effectiveness. The proceeds of the policy-based grant will be disbursed 
in  accordance  with  the  ADB  Loan  Disbursement  Handbook  (2017,  as  amended  from  time  to 
time).28 MOFT is the executing agency and one of the implementing agencies. The Office of the 
Prime Minister; the Ministry of Forestry and Research; the Ministry of Mines, Energy and Rural 
Electrification;  and  the  Ministry  of  Commerce,  Industry,  Labor  and  Immigration  will  also  be 
implementing agencies.  
 

Implementation Arrangements 

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

 
35. 
Following ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the program is classified category C 
for the environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples. No activity will result in or 
lead to involuntary resettlement or negatively affect indigenous peoples or the environment. 
 
36. 
The program is classified effective gender mainstreaming. Although women and men are 
both  active in the  labor force  in  almost  equal  numbers,  women  only  account for  3  of  every  10 
waged or salaried employees. Women tend to be employed in more informal and vulnerable types 
of work and, on average, earn 37% less in wages per year than men.29 There are many barriers 
to women’s economic empowerment in Solomon Islands including the lack of parity in education, 
the burden of unpaid care and housework, unequal decision-making power and limited control of 
financial resources, and challenges in accessing finance. The program supports the improvement 
of  gender  outcomes  across  all  three  reform  areas  and  will  support  women’s  economic 
empowerment by (i) including a gender analysis and consultations with women organizations in 
the tax review as well as a gender analysis in the PFM Action Plan, 2018–2019; (ii) approving a 
competition  policy  that  ensures  that  reviews  of  policies  and  practices  will  facilitate,  not  hinder, 
women’s  access  to  economic resources  and  opportunities;  (iii)  approving  an  anticorruption  act 
that supports an environment that is safe and fair for women to do business and ensures that at 
least two out of the six members of the Independent Anticorruption Commission are women; and 
(iv) reducing women’s time burden of unpaid care and housework by ensuring sufficient revenue 
for investments in social services.

The program is expected to have positive social outcomes.30 The public sector is a key 
37. 
provider of infrastructure and services to low-income households. Improved fiscal management 
will help ensure that the government has the resources to respond to future economic shocks, 
which tend to have an adverse effect on the poor, while maintaining critical public services. The 
government agreed to comply with ADB’s information disclosure and consultation requirements. 
 
38.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 2 and described in detail in 
the  risk  assessment  and  risk  management  plan.31 PFM  systems  are  assessed  as  capable  of 
supporting  mostly  reliable  service  provision.  Policy  reforms  and  TA  support  will  address  other 
fiduciary risks. The overall risk of the operation is moderate. To mitigate the risks, the proposed 
program focuses on areas where the government has a strong record and has selected options 
for policy actions in the PPPF that would help maintain reform momentum beyond 2018. ADB’s 
Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed with MOFT.

safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement, as described in detail
